meanings.def: to travel on water using sails or an engine
examples: + adv./prep. to sail into harbour
The dinghy sailed smoothly across the lake.
The ferry sails from Newhaven to Dieppe.
one of the first people to sail around the world
The flotilla will sail north to Hawaii.
sail something to sail the Atlantic
In his young days he had sailed the seas.
Thor managed to sail his raft across the Pacific Ocean.
Far out I could see a yacht with a white sail.
She will receive the profits from the sale of her property.
The boat sailed serenely on towards the horizon.
We sailed on a large ocean liner.
We were sailing from Dover to Calais.

meanings.def: to control or travel on a boat with a sail, especially as a sport
examples: We spent the weekend sailing off the south coast.
Do you go sailing often?
the first woman to sail solo around the world
sail something She sails her own yacht.
He managed to sail the boat between the rocks.
I learned to sail as a child.
We sailed the boat out into the middle of the lake.

meanings.def: to begin a journey on water
examples: We sail at 2 p.m. tomorrow.
sail for something He sailed for the West Indies from Portsmouth.
The ferry sails for Southampton at 5.30.

meanings.def: to move quickly and smoothly in a particular direction; (of people) to move in a confident manner
examples: clouds sailing across the sky
The ball sailed over the goalie's head.
She sailed past, ignoring me completely.
An owl sailed silently out of the branches.

meanings.def: to take a risk by doing something that is dangerous or that may be illegal

idioms.def: to take a risk by doing something that is dangerous or that may be illegal

meanings.def: a sheet of strong cloth which the wind blows against to make a boat or ship travel through the water
examples: As the boat moved down the river the wind began to fill the sails.
under sail a ship under sail (= using sails)
in the days of sail (= when ships all used sails)
She moved away like a ship in full sail (= with all its sails spread out).
The vessel can be propelled by oars or sail (= sails).
Thor managed to sail his raft across the Pacific Ocean.
Far out I could see a yacht with a white sail.
She will receive the profits from the sale of her property.
The bay was full of boats with billowing sails.
The boat is preserved as a monument to the days of sail.
The sails caught the wind once more and they were on their way.
The white canvas sail hung limply against the mast.
The ship came in under sail and anchored near us.

meanings.def: a trip in a boat or ship
examples: We went for a sail.
a two-hour sail across the bay
He took us for a sail up the river.

meanings.def: a set of boards attached to the arm of a windmill
to begin a trip by sea
examples: a liner setting sail from New York
We set sail (for France) at high tide.

meanings.def: to make somebody suddenly less confident or angry, especially when you do or say something that they do not expect
examples: When I agreed to his suggestion at once, it really took the wind out of his sails.

meanings.def: to arrange the sails of a boat to suit the wind so that the boat moves faster

idioms.def: to begin a trip by sea
examples: a liner setting sail from New York
We set sail (for France) at high tide.

idioms.idiom: take the wind out of somebody’s sails
idioms.def: to make somebody suddenly less confident or angry, especially when you do or say something that they do not expect
examples: When I agreed to his suggestion at once, it really took the wind out of his sails.

idioms.def: to arrange the sails of a boat to suit the wind so that the boat moves faster
